question: What factor causes the Sun to appear larger than other stars when viewed from Earth?

content.source_1: For objects of the same physical size, the one that is closer to the observer subtends a larger angle and therefore appears larger; in general, apparent angular size increases as distance decreases.
content.source_2: The Sun is about 1 astronomical unit (roughly 150 million kilometers) from Earth, whereas even the nearest other stars are more than four light-years away.
content.source_3: The Sun’s radius (~696,000 km) is larger than that of the majority of stars in the Milky Way, most of which are red dwarfs.
content.source_4: At a fixed distance from an observer, a physically larger star subtends a larger angular diameter than a smaller star and thus appears larger.
content.source_5: Earth is a planet—i.e., a celestial object—that orbits the Sun.
content.source_6: A star’s apparent angular size depends on both its physical diameter and its distance to the observer.
